citation.article-title: Hydrogenoanaerobacterium saccharovorans gen. nov., sp. nov., isolated from H2-producing UASB granules.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Hydrogenoanaerobacterium saccharovorans sp. nov.
Hydrogenoanaerobacterium saccharovorans (sac.cha.ro.vo′rans. Gr. n. saccharon sugar; L. part. adj. vorans devouring, digesting; N.L. part. adj. saccharovorans sugar-digesting).
Surface colonies on PYG agar are smooth, circular, white, semi-opaque and 1.0–1.5 mm in diameter after cultivation at 37 °C for 48 h.
Grows at 24–45 °C (no growth at ≤22 °C or ≥46 °C), with optimum growth at 37 °C.
The pH range for growth is 4.5–9.0 (no growth at pH≤4.2 or pH≥9.3), with optimum growth at pH 6.5–7.0.
Oxidase and catalase are not produced.
Acid is produced from a number of sugars, including glycogen, raffinose, sucrose, glucose, ribose, mannose, lactose, arabinose, maltose, inulin and trehalose.
Acid is not produced from glycerol, mannitol, fructose, xylose, sorbitol, cellobiose, rhamnose, inositol, salicin or starch.
Complex substrates such as yeast extract and peptone are also fermented.
The major end products of glucose fermentation are ethanol, acetate, hydrogen and carbon dioxide according to the equation 1 mol glucose→1.1 mol acetate+0.6 mol ethanol+2.6 mol H2+1.6 mol CO2.
H2S, but not indole, is produced on PYG.
The major cellular fatty acids are C16 : 0, C14 : 0, iso-C17 : 1ω9c, iso-C15 : 0 and iso-C13 : 0.
The type strain, SW512T (=AS 1.5070T=JCM 14861T), was isolated from a laboratory-scale UASB reactor at ambient temperature.
The DNA G+C content of the type strain is 41.9±0.5 mol%.
